newsitem.title: SWEDEN: Unemployment seems to have peaked-Sweden FinMin.
newsitem.headline: Unemployment seems to have peaked-Sweden FinMin.

text.p: Sweden's Finance Minister Erik Asbrink said on Tuesday that unemployment appeared to have peaked but it was impossible to say categorically.
"There is a lot of talk saying that unemployment had hit its peak. But you can never be 100 percent sure," Asbrink told reporters after a party meeting.
He said most forecasts estimated unemployment would fall this year and fall even further next year.
In February Swedish unemployment was running at 8.8 percent.
Asbrink repeated that his government wanted to halve open unemployment by the year 2000.
"We must start to notice it this year and in 1998," he said.
Asbrink said it was important that the government continued to pursue a political direction that gave strong public finances and low inflation.
Asbrink said it was vital that there was confidence in Swedish economic policies.
"We have won back a lot of confidence," he said. "It is important that we stick to strong public finances and low inflation. It is vital for employment."
